rmk: There were 4 red wattled lapwing. Two were fighting with each other. Most probably for acquiring a mate.

A pair of horses were feeding on grass in a paddock and I was watching some Mynas using them to get at the prey stirred up. I spotted one horse straying near a pair of Red-wattled Lapwings (Vanellus indicus atronuchalis) that were nesting on the ground (their nesting spot for many years). The horse fed all around the bird but did not disturb the nesting bird. The nesting Lapwing was very tolerant and stayed on the nest watching intently and protecting the eggs. The horse then decided to have a ‘rub-down’ on the grass. Unfortunately the long tail brushed against the nesting site. The Lapwing parent immediately got up and ‘screamed’ at the horse making a threatening posture. These were very loud, discrete calls that I have never heard before (not in literature). The horse responded quickly by getting up and moving away. Throughout the episode, the Lapwing did not move from the nest site and stayed to protect eggs. The partner was watching vigilantly but did not interfere. Note that these horses are released into this paddock on a daily basis. I am sure the birds (resident there) and horses know each other well and the intrusion on the nest was accidental. An edited recording of the second half of the calls is available here. The sonogram and waveform show that the calls are layered at multiple frequencies up to 16-17 kHz and have a ‘tower’ structure followed by a ‘drag’ component. There is no order or sequence to the calls. They were the ‘screams’ of a distressed parent protecting their nest.

rmk: natural vocalization; calls from a small group of this species near a large pond surrounded by fairly open savanna and dense dry forest.  The first, louder series of calls are from a pair of birds given immediately after mating.  The quieter, more jumbled series that follows comes from a trio of birds close by, and the louder calls near the end are from a single bird further away.

Was the recording modified significantly? No
Habitat: Table top, grassland ecosystem.
Behavior: Two individuals, male and female nesting. Aggressively defending the entire area.

rmk: This is a recording of three lapwings on the ground in a large mangosteen orchard.  The lapwings were calling before I approached, and continued calling as they flew off.  I think that one or more may have been nesting nearby because one continued to fly and circled overhead until I departed.  The main north-south coastal highway is about 300 meters distant and the recording has some local automobile and truck traffic.
Pair of birds, probably preparing to nest in area. Flying and calling in alarm when approached.

file-name: XC173180-054 Lapwing - Red-wattled (Vanellus indicus) Song 330m BanKrang Kaengkrachan THA_GI.mp3

rmk: Sunny and windy morning. Bird (and later its mate joined too) mobbed recordist over a particular zone, circling overhead and incessantly calling. Certainly alarm call as the recordist perhaps inadvertently came close to its nesting site. Other waders in the area weren't too bothered by the alarm calls. Higher resolution (24 bit 96 kHz) original recording available.
Several birds settling in for the night along the shoreline of the Jheel, some calls given in flight as they circled out over the mud flats.
